title: Angel City FC takes Hollywood grit to NWSL playoffs
body_text:
Going Hollywood isnâ€™t meant as a compliment.
Itâ€™s a knock on superficiality, a dig suggesting image trumps substance. â€œHollywoodâ€ being all glitz and glamour, life-of-luxury stuff.
Except thatâ€™s a facade. And a good one.
Because Hollywood is hard.
You probably know some of them, so youâ€™d agree: Like athletes, people in that business rely on resilience and guts as much as talent and luck. Without it, they couldnâ€™t survive the near-constant rejection, and they wouldnâ€™t put themselves out there to chase their dreams in the first place.
And if you know one thing about Angel City FC, itâ€™s that it is the professional womenâ€™s soccer team in L.A. with the star-studded majority female ownership group, right? Natalie Portman, Christina Aguilera, Jessica Chastain, Jennifer Garner, America Ferrera and so on â€¦
That gives it the appearance of a glitzy, glamorous operation, yes. And it made for an effectively splashy introduction last season, for sure.
But it also makes Angel City a fantastic representative of its city. Especially if you stop and consider the grit and determination thatâ€™s being represented by the A-gamers on the pitch and the A-list owners in the stands.
Together, theyâ€™ve delivered a NWSL playoff berth to L.A. for the first time: Angel City is the fifth seed, facing the fourth-seeded OL Reign on Friday at 7 p.m. in Seattle (watch on Paramount+).
â€œWhat we have here is people who are ambitious,â€ said Becki Tweed, Angel Cityâ€™s interim head coach (interim in name only, Iâ€™d assume, considering the team is campaigning for her to win NWSL Coach of the Year after she engineered a momentous midseason turnaround).
â€œPeople who are really intentional about growing womenâ€™s sports and about visibility and being seen.â€
And also winning. Clearly.
â€œWe play in L.A., theyâ€™re not very nice to you if you donâ€™t win,â€ defender Madison Hammond said on a video conference with reporters Thursday. â€œThatâ€™s what the whole point of this has been â€¦ and now to kind of translate all of what people call our off-field hype and translate that onto our on-field hype, thatâ€™s why it was so special for us to make playoffs.â€
Believe it. Angel City ran an 11:11-make-a-wish play to perfection, going on an 11-game unbeaten streak that lifted it from 11th place in the 12-team league into the running for the postseason, all while it navigated injuries and the absences of four World Cup players. (Alyssa Thompson and Julie Ertz played for the United States, Jun Endo for Japan and Ali Riley for New Zealand.)
Angel Cityâ€™s resurgence began as soon as Tweed took over for Freya Coombe, who was fired halfway through the 22-game season, back when Angel City did look like it was all hype, with a record of two wins against six losses and three draws.
The reversal came with a bit of foreshadowing: a 2-1 comeback thriller over the top-seeded San Diego Wave, Angel Cityâ€™s rival, on the road at Snapdragon Stadium.
And it continued in Sundayâ€™s regular-season finale with the best performance in the franchiseâ€™s young history, a most-validating 5-1 victory over the Portland Thorns FC â€“ Angel Cityâ€™s biggest margin of victory in its biggest match yet, because the win nudged the team off a crowded bubble and into the postseason along with five other squads.
But this is no fairy tale. Itâ€™s not as if the other NWSL teams have been sticking to a script on Angel Cityâ€™s behalf.
This is the result, Tweed said, of buy-in and belief. Of players being able to be honest and vulnerable in their roles. And of dealing with so much pressure since June that pressure doesnâ€™t feel much like pressure anymore.
And so I get it when Angel City players like Riley, the team captain, say they want to ditch the â€œHollywoodâ€ label.
â€œThis team just fights,â€ she told reporters earlier this week. â€œI donâ€™t think that would be the first image people think of when we have this Hollywood atmosphere, but thatâ€™s been the defining identity of this team.â€
Or as defender Sarah Gorden put it postgame Sunday: â€œI know weâ€™re in Hollywood, but weâ€™ve never, ever played like that.â€
I think, though, if weâ€™re talking about the real Hollywood, the cutthroat and competitive town that rewards outsized resolve and requires enormous drive?
They are so Hollywood.
So get your popcorn ready, because the way this much-ballyhooed upstart of a team is trending, we might see a fitting ending on this location.
